column1: # Party control of Congress and the Presidency.
# This table was transcribed from the Wikipedia page at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Party_divisions_of_United_States_Congresses on May 24, 2014.

# a) In the 107th Congress where party control changed mid-Congress, I've broken the Congress into multiple rows and indicated the date range accordingly. In the first two rows, party control was decided by the tie-breaking vote of the VP.
# b) Where third-party members caucused with one of the major parties, I've moved their counts into the major parties.
# c) In the 111th Congress, I took the party counts at the end of the Congress. (There were no power changes during the Congress, but the counts changed mid-Congress.)
# Note that the "Democrats" and "Republicans" columns represented different parties in early Congresses:
# * In the 1st-3rd Congresses, the "Democrats" in this table represented the "Anti-Administration" party, and in the 4th-18th Congresses the "Democratic-Republican" party.

# * In the 1st-3rd Congresses, the "Republicans" in this table represented the "Pro-Administration" party, in the 3th-18th Congresses the "Federalists", in the 19th-24th Congresses the "National Republicans", and in the 25th-33rd Congresses the "Whigs".
